intro: Helianthopsis bishopii, commonly known as the Bishop's sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, hairy stems. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its yellow-orange flower heads bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Helianthopsis bishopii is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in local ecosystems.
